Legal_Issue: Whether the citizenship judge erred in determining applicants did not meet residency requirements under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Applicants had significant absences from Canada and provided incomplete documentation
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the citizenship judge's decision
Defendant_Behavior: Citizenship judge applied legal standard and assessed evidence
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error in residency requirement assessment
Assessment_Factor: Physical presence in Canada over a four-year period
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review under the Federal Courts Act
Credibility_Assessment: Insufficient evidence of physical presence; documentation deemed incomplete
Evidence_Used: Residency records, travel history, application documents
Application_Basis: Requirement of at least 1,095 days of physical residence in Canada within four years prior to application
Evidence_Assessed: Documentation of time spent in Canada
Governing_Rule: Applicants must accumulate at least three years (1,095 days) of residence in Canada within four years preceding application
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Incomplete documentation and lack of proof of physical presence
Harm_Assessment: No harm established; decision found reasonable
Cause_Description: Applications denied due to perceived non-compliance with residency requirements
Evidence_Handling: Judge evaluated submitted documents and found them insufficient
Residency_Compliance: Not met – insufficient days of physical presence documented
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction under the Federal Courts Act
Evidence_Assessment: Negative – evidence failed to establish required residency
Decision_Rationale: The judge’s interpretation and application of the residency requirement was reasonable
Evidentiary_Issues: Incomplete and insufficient documentation to prove residency
